I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to support improvements in its public sector management operations 
in order to safeguard and expand fiscal space in pursuit of sustainable growth and the equitable 
delivery of public services. The government has requested ADB’s support in three interrelated 
areas:  public  expenditure  management;  revenue  management  and  tax  data  analysis;  and 
corporate governance of state-owned enterprises (SOEs),  especially in relation to financial 
planning and management.1 ADB will deliver the support through a combination of analytical work, 
policy recommendations, and capacity development. 
 
2.  The knowledge and support TA is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
Mongolia, 2017–2020, which identifies public sector management as a key driver of sustained 
inclusive economic growth.2 The TA is included in the country operations and business plan for 
Mongolia, 2020–2021.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Mongolia’s key development challenge is to build a resilient and diversified economy that 
is less dependent on mining revenues, can foster sustainable and inclusive growth, and ensures 
the equitable delivery of public services.4 A dependence on mining revenues, and the associated 
vulnerability to price fluctuations in international commodity markets, has made Mongolia’s 
macroeconomic and fiscal performance highly volatile. Since 1995, the country has experienced 
three recessions and entered in six International Monetary Fund (IMF) programs. The 2016 crisis 
of twin deficits (fiscal and balance of payments) could be traced to two main structural problems: 
(i) persistent fiscal deficits and growing public debt, mostly associated with nonprudent fiscal 
management and lack of fiscal buffers; and (ii) unsustainable balance of payment deficits linked 
to undiversified sources of foreign exchange (such as single-product and single-client exports, an 
economic structure dependent on mining, a predominance of foreign direct investment, and 
growing sovereign debt). These boom–bust cycles risk undermining the standard of living gains. 
The sudden deceleration of economic growth during 2014–2016 led to a fall in employment growth 
and real wages, and an increase in poverty.5 
 
4.  In addition, Mongolia is experiencing a severe economic slowdown because of the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. The turmoil in the global economy, capital markets, 
and commodity markets because of the COVID-19 pandemic has weakened Mongolia’s economic 
outlook. Consequently, gross domestic product (GDP) growth will be much lower in 2020 than

areas in response to the changing needs and demands of the country. Areas of support have included legal and 
regulatory reform, public financial management, public administration reform, sovereign wealth management, and 
SOE reform. A key high-level lesson is that Mongolia’s inherently volatile economic and fiscal environment makes 
public sector reform even more challenging, and this must be factored into the pace, complexity, and political 
feasibility of reforms. ADB. 2018. Mongolia: Public Sector Management Factsheet. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2020–2021. Manila. The TA was listed as Improving Fiscal 
Management. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 19 August 2020. 
4  This has been well-documented in various publications, including ADB. 2019. Asian Development Outlook 2019: 
Strengthening Disaster Resilience. Manila; and IMF. 2019. Article IV Report for Mongolia. Washington, DC. 
5  World Bank Group. 2018. Mongolia Systematic Country Diagnostics. Washington, DC.

2 
envisioned; ADB has revised the 2020 GDP growth forecast from 6.1%6 to –1.9%.7 A protracted 
global economic downturn would worsen this outlook considerably, possibly resulting in sustained 
negative growth and requiring support beyond the scope of this intervention. 
 
5.  This potentially bleak economic outlook, combined with sizable external debt repayments, 
including maturing bonds during 2020–2024, presents important challenges for Mongolia’s fiscal 
policy and public financial management.8 This requires careful fiscal management along the lines 
of the Law on Fiscal Stability (2010) and close expenditure management to ensure that these 
generate strong value for money and reduce economic vulnerabilities.9 
 
6.  The  Action  Program  of  the  Government  of  Mongolia  for  2016–2020  explicitly 
acknowledges that a well-functioning public administration and civil service, underpinned by 
effective  and  efficient  public  sector  management  systems  and  processes,  is  a  necessary 
precondition to successfully manage the economy under such volatile circumstances.10 However,  
the strategic allocation and efficient use of public financial resources are hampered by  (i) 
inefficiencies in expenditure management and domestic resource mobilization, including tax 
policy and tax administration; and (ii) weak corporate governance, in particular the financial 
planning and management capacity of SOEs. 
 
7.  Expenditure management. Mongolia’s capital expenditures averaged about 11% of GDP 
during 2010–2016, far exceeding those of lower middle-income countries (4.8%) and East Asia 
and Pacific (3.0%). Total capital spending increased from 6.1% of GDP in 2010 to 12.4% in 2013, 
and then declined to 6.0% in 2015 before rising again to 9.9% in 2016. The composition of public 
expenditure has been skewed toward investment as line ministries continue to prioritize new 
projects over the provision of adequate funding for operation and maintenance of capital assets.11 
 
8.  Moreover, Mongolia’s public expenditure efficiency is low. The country ranked 102nd of 
141 countries on efficiency of public spending in the 2019 Global Competitiveness Index.12 The 
IMF’s 2016 Public Investment Management Assessment for Mongolia revealed poor performance 
in public investment management practices.13 Mongolia’s scores are much lower than those of its 
emerging market comparators. Weak public expenditure management has led to poor project 
selection, long project implementation delays, high cost overruns, and rapid deterioration of 
assets, thereby contributing to low investment productivity and spending efficiency. Improving 
public investment efficiency should therefore be a high priority. 
 
 
6  ADB. 2019. Asian Development Outlook 2019: Strengthening Disaster Resilience. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2020. Asian Development Outlook Supplement 2020: Lockdown, Loosening, and Asia’s Growth Prospects 
Manila. 
8  Mongolia’s total external debt repayment obligations during 2020–2024, including international bonds, external loans, 
and government guarantees, are forecast to be $5.9 billion. 
9  Mongolia could benefit from (i) ADB policy-based guarantees to improve the terms of commercial debt by extending 
maturity, lowering interest rate costs, increasing issue amount and/or enabling access to new markets (loans and 
bonds), making commercial debt more suitable for development support (e.g., infrastructure projects and budgetary 
financing); and (ii) a pool of TA funds that ADB has set aside to strengthen debt management in its group B and C 
countries. Discussions in this regard are currently ongoing between ADB’s East Asia Department and the Strategy, 
Policy and Partnerships Department. Support for the preparation of a possible policy-based guarantee has been 
included in the terms of reference of the international public expenditure management specialist and the resident TA 
and portfolio coordinator. 
10  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Action Program of the Government of Mongolia for 2016–2020. Ulaanbaatar.  
11  World Bank. 2018. Growing Without Undue Borrowing–Enhancing Efficiency of Spending and Revenue. Washington, 
DC/Ulaanbaatar. 
12  World Economic Forum. 2019. The Global Competitiveness Report 2019. Geneva. 
13  The assessment is prepared by the IMF but is not disclosed publicly.

3 
9.  Domestic resource mobilization—tax policy and administration. Mongolia’s revenue 
performance has been highly volatile because of its exposure to global swings in commodity 
prices. Policy recommendations to mitigate this volatility have included (i) strengthening sovereign 
wealth management in line with international good governance and investment practices (e.g., 
through the independent offshore management of assets);14 (ii) increasing the non-mining share 
of overall tax revenue; (iii) increasing the comparatively low statutory taxes; (iv) reducing the high 
number of tax exemptions; and (v) strengthening tax collection and administration. The adoption 
and implementation of these recommendations have been hampered by the absence of a 
comprehensive  assessment  of  the  institutional  arrangements  that  drive  domestic  resource 
mobilization. As a result, policy decisions on revenue management reforms and administrative 
strengthening have not always been evidence-based and have tended to fail. 
 
10.  State-owned enterprise financial planning and management. A 2019 assessment by 
Mongolia’s Government Agency for Policy Coordination on State Property (PCSP) found that 
establishing and maintaining good corporate governance standards in SOEs is essential to 
increase the efficiency of their operations.15 The PCSP highlighted poor capacity for financial 
analysis, planning, and management as a key corporate governance weakness that undermines 
the efficiency of SOE operations, and considers strengthening this capacity to be a priority. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: create an effective and responsible fiscal 
system aimed at the efficient use of financial resources for socioeconomic development.16 The 
TA will have the following outcome: government’s management of public finances and fiscal 
stability strengthened.17 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
12.  Output 1: Public expenditure efficiency enhanced. In close consultation with the 
government  and  relevant  development  partners,  the  TA  will  support  the  preparation  and 
implementation of a strategic, policy, and technical road map that lays out measures to improve 
the efficiency of public expenditures, focusing on aggregate fiscal discipline, strategic prioritization 
(allocative efficiency), and operational performance (technical efficiency). 
 
13.  Output 2: Institutional capacity for domestic resource mobilization improved. In line 
with a strategic road map that is being developed with IMF assistance, the TA will support the  
(i)  review  of  strengths  and  weaknesses  in  the  policy,  legal,  and  institutional 
framework for domestic resource mobilization; 
(ii)  identification of factors hindering the protection and optimization of domestic 
revenue streams; maximization of revenue collection; implementation of effective

(iii)  preparation  of  recommendations  for  institutional  strengthening  for  effective 
domestic resource mobilization, and creation and expansion of fiscal buffers; and  
(iv)  implementation of identified institutional strengthening measures.18 
 
14.  Output 3: Road map on state-owned enterprise corporate governance, including 
financial planning and management, developed. The TA will support the development of a 
strategic  road  map  for  SOE  reforms  in  Mongolia  that  are  essential  to  ensure  SOEs’ 
competitiveness, efficiency, and fiscal sustainability. The road map will be informed by national 
and sector diagnostics that will benchmark SOE governance and financial planning capacity 
against established international standards and will be used to identify major gaps and risk areas.  
The development of the road map will be complemented by capacity-building for the PCSP on 
SOE planning and financial management.19 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which $750,000 which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6).20 The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
16.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff, 
secretarial assistance, office accommodation, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency will be the Ministry of Finance, and the 
implementing agencies will be Ministry of Finance, the General Department of Taxation, and the 
Agency for Policy Coordination on State Property.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the

Mongolia, for Support for Effective Public Sector Management, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
